en/admin-settings/admin-settings.title: Authentication, Permissions and Global Configuration
en/admin-settings/admin-settings.description: After installation, the system administrator should configure Rancher to configure authentication, authorization, security, default settings, security policies, drivers and global DNS entries.

en/admin-settings/authentication/ad/ad.title: Configuring Active Directory (AD)
en/admin-settings/authentication/ad/ad.description: If your organization uses Microsoft Active Directory as central user repository, you can configure Rancher to communicate with an Active Directory server to authenticate users. This allows Rancher admins to control access to clusters and projects based on users and groups managed externally in the Active Directory, while allowing end-users to authenticate with their AD credentials when logging in to the Rancher UI.

en/admin-settings/authentication/authent.title: Authentication
en/admin-settings/authentication/authent.description: One of the key features that Rancher adds to Kubernetes is centralized user authentication. This feature allows your users to use one set of credentials to authenticate with any of your Kubernetes clusters.

en/admin-settings/authentication/azure-a.title: Configuring Azure AD
en/admin-settings/authentication/azure-a.description: If you have an instance of Active Directory (AD) hosted in Azure, you can configure Rancher to allow your users to log in using their AD accounts. Configuration of Azure AD external authentication requires you to make configurations in both Azure and Rancher.

en/admin-settings/authentication/freeipa.title: Configuring FreeIPA
en/admin-settings/authentication/freeipa.description: If your organization uses FreeIPA for user authentication, you can configure Rancher to allow your users to login using their FreeIPA credentials.

en/admin-settings/authentication/github/.title: Configuring GitHub
en/admin-settings/authentication/github/.description: In environments using GitHub, you can configure Rancher to allow sign on using GitHub credentials.

en/admin-settings/authentication/google/.title: Configuring Google OAuth
en/admin-settings/authentication/google/.description: If your organization uses G Suite for user authentication, you can configure Rancher to allow your users to log in using their G Suite credentials.

en/admin-settings/authentication/keycloa.title: Configuring Keycloak (OIDC)
en/admin-settings/authentication/keycloa.description: Create a Keycloak OpenID Connect (OIDC) client and configure Rancher to work with Keycloak. By the end your users will be able to sign into Rancher using their Keycloak logins

en/admin-settings/authentication/keycloa.title: Configuring Keycloak (SAML)
en/admin-settings/authentication/keycloa.description: Create a Keycloak SAML client and configure Rancher to work with Keycloak. By the end your users will be able to sign into Rancher using their Keycloak logins

en/admin-settings/authentication/local/l.title: Local Authentication
en/admin-settings/authentication/local/l.description: Local authentication is the default until you configure an external authentication provider. Local authentication is where Rancher stores the user information, i.e. names and passwords, of who can log in to Rancher. By default, the admin user that logs in to Rancher for the first time is a local user.

en/admin-settings/authentication/microso.title: Configuring Microsoft Active Directory Federation Service (SAML)
en/admin-settings/authentication/microso.description: If your organization uses Microsoft Active Directory Federation Services (AD FS) for user authentication, you can configure Rancher to allow your users to log in using their AD FS credentials.

en/admin-settings/authentication/microso.title: 1. Configuring Microsoft AD FS for Rancher
en/admin-settings/authentication/microso.description: Before configuring Rancher to support AD FS users, you must add Rancher as a relying party trust in AD FS.

en/admin-settings/authentication/microso.title: 2. Configuring Rancher for Microsoft AD FS
en/admin-settings/authentication/microso.description: After you complete Configuring Microsoft AD FS for Rancher, enter your AD FS information into Rancher to allow AD FS users to authenticate with Rancher.

en/admin-settings/authentication/okta/ok.title: Configuring Okta (SAML)
en/admin-settings/authentication/okta/ok.description: If your organization uses Okta Identity Provider (IdP) for user authentication, you can configure Rancher to allow your users to log in using their IdP credentials.

en/admin-settings/authentication/openlda.title: Configuring OpenLDAP
en/admin-settings/authentication/openlda.description: If your organization uses LDAP for user authentication, you can configure Rancher to communicate with an OpenLDAP server to authenticate users. This allows Rancher admins to control access to clusters and projects based on users and groups managed externally in the organisation's central user repository, while allowing end-users to authenticate with their LDAP credentials when logging in to the Rancher UI.

en/admin-settings/authentication/openlda.title: OpenLDAP Configuration Reference
en/admin-settings/authentication/openlda.description: This section is intended to be used as a reference when setting up an OpenLDAP authentication provider in Rancher.

en/admin-settings/authentication/ping-fe.title: Configuring PingIdentity (SAML)
en/admin-settings/authentication/ping-fe.description: If your organization uses Ping Identity Provider (IdP) for user authentication, you can configure Rancher to allow your users to log in using their IdP credentials.

en/admin-settings/authentication/shibbol.title: Group Permissions with Shibboleth and OpenLDAP
en/admin-settings/authentication/shibbol.description: This page provides background information and context for Rancher users who intend to set up the Shibboleth authentication provider in Rancher.

en/admin-settings/authentication/shibbol.title: Configuring Shibboleth (SAML)
en/admin-settings/authentication/shibbol.description: If your organization uses Shibboleth Identity Provider (IdP) for user authentication, you can configure Rancher to allow your users to log in to Rancher using their Shibboleth credentials.

en/admin-settings/authentication/user-gr.title: Users and Groups
en/admin-settings/authentication/user-gr.description: Rancher relies on users and groups to determine who is allowed to log in to Rancher and which resources they can access. When you configure an external authentication provider, users from that provider will be able to log in to your Rancher server. When a user logs in, the authentication provider will supply your Rancher server with a list of groups to which the user belongs.

en/admin-settings/branding/branding.title: Custom Branding
en/admin-settings/branding/branding.description: Rancher v2.6 introduced the ability to customize Rancherâ€™s branding and navigation links.

en/admin-settings/cluster-templates/clus.title: Cluster Templates
en/admin-settings/cluster-templates/clus.description: Cluster templates encompass both Kubernetes configuration and node pool configuration, allowing a single template to contain all the information Rancher needs to provision new nodes in a cloud provider and install Kubernetes on those nodes.

en/admin-settings/config-private-registr.title: Configuring a Global Default Private Registry
en/admin-settings/config-private-registr.description: You might want to use a private container registry to share your custom base images within your organization. With a private registry, you can keep a private, consistent, and centralized source of truth for the container images that are used in your clusters.

en/admin-settings/drivers/cluster-driver.title: Cluster Drivers
en/admin-settings/drivers/cluster-driver.description: Cluster drivers are used to create clusters in a hosted Kubernetes provider, such as Google GKE. The availability of which cluster driver to display when creating clusters is defined by the cluster driver's status. Only active cluster drivers will be displayed as an option for creating clusters. By default, Rancher is packaged with several existing cloud provider cluster drivers, but you can also add custom cluster drivers to Rancher.

en/admin-settings/drivers/drivers.title: Provisioning Drivers
en/admin-settings/drivers/drivers.description: Drivers in Rancher allow you to manage which providers can be used to deploy hosted Kubernetes clusters or nodes in an infrastructure provider to allow Rancher to deploy and manage Kubernetes.

en/admin-settings/drivers/node-drivers/n.title: Node Drivers
en/admin-settings/drivers/node-drivers/n.description: Node drivers are used to provision hosts, which Rancher uses to launch and manage Kubernetes clusters. A node driver is the same as a Docker Machine driver. The availability of which node driver to display when creating node templates is defined based on the node driver's status. Only active node drivers will be displayed as an option for creating node templates. By default, Rancher is packaged with many existing Docker Machine drivers, but you can also create custom node drivers to add to Rancher.

en/admin-settings/k8s-metadata/k8s-metad.title: Upgrading Kubernetes without Upgrading Rancher
en/admin-settings/k8s-metadata/k8s-metad.description: The RKE metadata feature allows you to provision clusters with new versions of Kubernetes as soon as they are released, without upgrading Rancher. This feature is useful for taking advantage of patch versions of Kubernetes, for example, if you want to upgrade to Kubernetes v1.14.7 when your Rancher server originally supported v1.14.6.

en/admin-settings/pod-security-policies/.title: Pod Security Policies
en/admin-settings/pod-security-policies/.description: Pod Security Policies (or PSPs) are objects that control security-sensitive aspects of pod specification (like root privileges).

en/admin-settings/rbac/cluster-project-r.title: Cluster and Project Roles
en/admin-settings/rbac/cluster-project-r.description: Cluster and project roles define user authorization inside a cluster or project.

en/admin-settings/rbac/default-custom-ro.title: Custom Roles
en/admin-settings/rbac/default-custom-ro.description: Within Rancher, roles determine what actions a user can make within a cluster or project.

en/admin-settings/rbac/global-permission.title: Global Permissions
en/admin-settings/rbac/global-permission.description: Permissions are individual access rights that you can assign when selecting a custom permission for a user.

en/admin-settings/rbac/locked-roles/lock.title: Locked Roles
en/admin-settings/rbac/locked-roles/lock.description: You can set roles to a status of locked. Locking roles prevent them from being assigned to users in the future.

en/admin-settings/rbac/rbac.title: Role-Based Access Control (RBAC)
en/admin-settings/rbac/rbac.description: Within Rancher, each person authenticates as a user, which is a login that grants you access to Rancher. As mentioned in Authentication, users can either be local or external.

en/admin-settings/rke-templates/applying.title: Applying Templates
en/admin-settings/rke-templates/applying.description: You can create a cluster from an RKE template that you created, or from a template that has been shared with you.

en/admin-settings/rke-templates/creating.title: Creating and Revising RKE Templates
en/admin-settings/rke-templates/creating.description: This section describes how to manage RKE templates and revisions. You an create, share, update, and delete templates from the Cluster Management view under RKE1 Configuration > RKE Templates.

en/admin-settings/rke-templates/creator-.title: Template Creator Permissions
en/admin-settings/rke-templates/creator-.description: Administrators have the permission to create RKE templates, and only administrators can give that permission to other users.

en/admin-settings/rke-templates/enforcem.title: Template Enforcement
en/admin-settings/rke-templates/enforcem.description: This section describes how template administrators can enforce templates in Rancher, restricting the ability of users to create clusters without a template.

en/admin-settings/rke-templates/example-.title: Example Scenarios
en/admin-settings/rke-templates/example-.description: These example scenarios describe how an organization could use templates to standardize cluster creation.

en/admin-settings/rke-templates/example-.title: Example YAML
en/admin-settings/rke-templates/example-.description: Below is an example RKE template configuration file for reference.

en/admin-settings/rke-templates/override.title: Overriding Template Settings
en/admin-settings/rke-templates/override.description: When a user creates an RKE template, each setting in the template has a switch in the Rancher UI that indicates if users can override the setting. This switch marks those settings as Allow User Override.

en/admin-settings/rke-templates/rke-temp.title: RKE Templates
en/admin-settings/rke-templates/rke-temp.description: RKE templates are designed to allow DevOps and security teams to standardize and simplify the creation of Kubernetes clusters.

en/admin-settings/rke-templates/rke-temp.title: RKE Templates and Infrastructure
en/admin-settings/rke-templates/rke-temp.description: In Rancher, RKE templates are used to provision Kubernetes and define Rancher settings, while node templates are used to provision nodes.

en/admin-settings/rke-templates/template.title: Access and Sharing
en/admin-settings/rke-templates/template.description: If you are an RKE template owner, you can share it with users or groups of users, who can then use the template to create clusters.

en/api/api-tokens/api-tokens.title: API Tokens
en/api/api-tokens/api-tokens.description: By default, some cluster-level API tokens are generated with infinite time-to-live (ttl=0). In other words, API tokens with ttl=0 never expire unless you invalidate them. Tokens are not invalidated by changing a password.

en/backups/back-up-rancher/back-up-ranch.title: Backing up Rancher
en/backups/back-up-rancher/back-up-ranch.description: In this section, you'll learn how to back up Rancher running on any Kubernetes cluster. To backup Rancher installed with Docker, refer the instructions for single node backups

en/backups/backups.title: Backups and Disaster Recovery
en/backups/backups.description: In this section, you'll learn how to create backups of Rancher, how to restore Rancher from backup, and how to migrate Rancher to a new Kubernetes cluster.

en/backups/configuration/backup-config/b.title: Backup Configuration
en/backups/configuration/backup-config/b.description: The Backup Create page lets you configure a schedule, enable encryption and specify the storage location for your backups.

en/backups/configuration/restore-config/.title: Restore Configuration
en/backups/configuration/restore-config/.description: The Restore Create page lets you provide details of the backup to restore from

en/backups/configuration/storage-config/.title: Backup Storage Location Configuration
en/backups/configuration/storage-config/.description: Configure a storage location where all backups are saved by default. You will have the option to override this with each backup, but will be limited to using an S3-compatible object store.

en/backups/docker-installs/docker-backup.title: Backing up Rancher Installed with Docker
en/backups/docker-installs/docker-backup.description: After completing your Docker installation of Rancher, we recommend creating backups of it on a regular basis. Having a recent backup will let you recover quickly from an unexpected disaster.

en/backups/docker-installs/docker-instal.title: Backup and Restore for Rancher Installed with Docker

en/backups/docker-installs/docker-restor.title: Restoring Backupsâ€”Docker Installs
en/backups/docker-installs/docker-restor.description: If you encounter a disaster scenario, you can restore your Rancher Server to your most recent backup.

en/backups/examples/examples.title: Examples
en/backups/examples/examples.description: This section contains examples of Backup and Restore custom resources.

en/backups/migrating-rancher/migrating-r.title: Migrating Rancher to a New Cluster
en/backups/migrating-rancher/migrating-r.description: If you are migrating Rancher to a new Kubernetes cluster, you don't need to install Rancher on the new cluster first. If Rancher is restored to a new cluster with Rancher already installed, it can cause problems.

en/backups/restoring-rancher/restoring-r.title: Restoring Rancher
en/backups/restoring-rancher/restoring-r.description: This page outlines how to perform a restore with Rancher.

en/best-practices/best-practices.title: Best Practices Guide
en/best-practices/best-practices.description: The purpose of this section is to consolidate best practices for Rancher implementations. This also includes recommendations for related technologies, such as Kubernetes, Docker, containers, and more. The objective is to improve the outcome of a Rancher implementation using the operational experience of Rancher and its customers.

en/best-practices/rancher-managed/contai.title: Tips for Setting Up Containers
en/best-practices/rancher-managed/contai.description: Running well-built containers can greatly impact the overall performance and security of your environment.

en/best-practices/rancher-managed/loggin.title: Logging Best Practices
en/best-practices/rancher-managed/loggin.description: In this guide, we recommend best practices for cluster-level logging and application logging.

en/best-practices/rancher-managed/manage.title: Best Practices for Rancher Managed vSphere Clusters
en/best-practices/rancher-managed/manage.description: This guide outlines a reference architecture for provisioning downstream Rancher clusters in a vSphere environment, in addition to standard vSphere best practices as documented by VMware.

en/best-practices/rancher-managed/monito.title: Monitoring Best Practices
en/best-practices/rancher-managed/monito.description: Configuring sensible monitoring and alerting rules is vital for running any production workloads securely and reliably. This is not different when using Kubernetes and Rancher. Fortunately the integrated monitoring and alerting functionality makes this whole process a lot easier.

en/best-practices/rancher-managed/ranche.title: Best Practices for Rancher Managed Clusters

en/best-practices/rancher-server/deploym.title: Rancher Deployment Strategy
en/best-practices/rancher-server/deploym.description: There are two recommended deployment strategies for a Rancher server that manages downstream Kubernetes clusters. Each one has its own pros and cons. Read more about which one would fit best for your use case:

en/best-practices/rancher-server/deploym.title: Tips for Running Rancher
en/best-practices/rancher-server/deploym.description: This guide is geared toward use cases where Rancher is used to manage downstream Kubernetes clusters. The high-availability setup is intended to prevent losing access to downstream clusters if the Rancher server is not available.

en/best-practices/rancher-server/rancher.title: Installing Rancher in a vSphere Environment
en/best-practices/rancher-server/rancher.description: This guide outlines a reference architecture for installing Rancher on an RKE Kubernetes cluster in a vSphere environment, in addition to standard vSphere best practices as documented by VMware.

en/best-practices/rancher-server/rancher.title: Best Practices for the Rancher Server
en/best-practices/rancher-server/rancher.description: This guide contains our recommendations for running the Rancher server, and is intended to be used in situations in which Rancher manages downstream Kubernetes clusters.

en/cis-scans/cis-scans.title: CIS Scans
en/cis-scans/cis-scans.description: Rancher can run a security scan to check whether Kubernetes is deployed according to security best practices as defined in the CIS Kubernetes Benchmark. The CIS scans can run on any Kubernetes cluster, including hosted Kubernetes providers such as EKS, AKS, and GKE.

en/cis-scans/configuration/configuration.title: Configuration
en/cis-scans/configuration/configuration.description: This configuration reference is intended to help you manage the custom resources created by the rancher-cis-benchmark application. These resources are used for performing CIS scans on a cluster, skipping tests, setting the test profile that will be used during a scan, and other customization.

en/cis-scans/custom-benchmark/custom-ben.title: Creating a Custom Benchmark Version for Running a Cluster Scan
en/cis-scans/custom-benchmark/custom-ben.description: Each Benchmark Version defines a set of test configuration files that define the CIS tests to be run by the kube-bench tool.

en/cis-scans/rbac/rbac.title: Roles-based Access Control
en/cis-scans/rbac/rbac.description: This section describes the permissions required to use the rancher-cis-benchmark App.

en/cis-scans/skipped-tests/skipped-tests.title: Skipped and Not Applicable Tests
en/cis-scans/skipped-tests/skipped-tests.description: This section lists the tests that are skipped in the permissive test profile for RKE.

en/cli/cli.title: CLI with Rancher
en/cli/cli.description: Interact with Rancher using command line interface (CLI) tools from your workstation.

en/cluster-admin/backing-up-etcd/backing.title: Backing up a Cluster
en/cluster-admin/backing-up-etcd/backing.description: In the Rancher UI, etcd backup and recovery for Rancher launched Kubernetes clusters can be easily performed.

en/cluster-admin/certificate-rotation/ce.title: Certificate Rotation
en/cluster-admin/certificate-rotation/ce.description: Warning: Rotating Kubernetes certificates may result in your cluster being temporarily unavailable as components are restarted. For production environments, it's recommended to perform this action during a maintenance window.

en/cluster-admin/cleaning-cluster-nodes/.title: Removing Kubernetes Components from Nodes
en/cluster-admin/cleaning-cluster-nodes/.description: Learn about cluster cleanup when removing nodes from your Rancher-launched Kubernetes cluster. What is removed, how to do it manually

en/cluster-admin/cloning-clusters/clonin.title: Cloning Clusters
en/cluster-admin/cloning-clusters/clonin.description: If you have a cluster in Rancher that you want to use as a template for creating similar clusters, you can use Rancher CLI to clone the cluster's configuration, edit it, and then use it to quickly launch the cloned cluster.

en/cluster-admin/cluster-access/ace/ace.title: How the Authorized Cluster Endpoint Works
en/cluster-admin/cluster-access/ace/ace.description: This section describes how the kubectl CLI, the kubeconfig file, and the authorized cluster endpoint work together to allow you to access a downstream Kubernetes cluster directly, without authenticating through the Rancher server. It is intended to provide background information and context to the instructions for how to set up kubectl to directly access a cluster.

en/cluster-admin/cluster-access/cluster-.title: Cluster Access
en/cluster-admin/cluster-access/cluster-.description: This section is about what tools can be used to access clusters managed by Rancher.

en/cluster-admin/cluster-access/cluster-.title: Adding Users to Clusters
en/cluster-admin/cluster-access/cluster-.description: If you want to provide a user with access and permissions to all projects, nodes, and resources within a cluster, assign the user a cluster membership.

en/cluster-admin/cluster-access/kubectl/.title: Access a Cluster with Kubectl and kubeconfig
en/cluster-admin/cluster-access/kubectl/.description: Learn how you can access and manage your Kubernetes clusters using kubectl with kubectl Shell or with kubectl CLI and kubeconfig file. A kubeconfig file is used to configure access to Kubernetes. When you create a cluster with Rancher, it automatically creates a kubeconfig for your cluster.

en/cluster-admin/cluster-admin.title: Cluster Administration
en/cluster-admin/cluster-admin.description: After you provision a cluster in Rancher, you can begin using powerful Kubernetes features to deploy and scale your containerized applications in development, testing, or production environments.

en/cluster-admin/cluster-autoscaler/amaz.title: Cluster Autoscaler with AWS EC2 Auto Scaling Groups
en/cluster-admin/cluster-autoscaler/amaz.description: This guide will show you how to install and use Kubernetes cluster-autoscaler on Rancher custom clusters using AWS EC2 Auto Scaling Groups.

en/cluster-admin/cluster-autoscaler/clus.title: Cluster Autoscaler
en/cluster-admin/cluster-autoscaler/clus.description: In this section, you'll learn how to install and use the Kubernetes cluster-autoscaler on Rancher custom clusters using AWS EC2 Auto Scaling Groups.

en/cluster-admin/editing-clusters/aks-co.title: AKS Cluster Configuration Reference
en/cluster-admin/editing-clusters/aks-co.description: - Support for adding more than one node pool

en/cluster-admin/editing-clusters/editin.title: Cluster Configuration
en/cluster-admin/editing-clusters/editin.description: After you provision a Kubernetes cluster using Rancher, you can still edit options and settings for the cluster.

en/cluster-admin/editing-clusters/gke-co.title: Private Clusters
en/cluster-admin/editing-clusters/gke-co.description: In GKE, private clusters are clusters whose nodes are isolated from inbound and outbound traffic by assigning them internal IP addresses only. Private clusters in GKE have the option of exposing the control plane endpoint as a publicly accessible address or as a private address. This is different from other Kubernetes providers, which may refer to clusters with private control plane endpoints as "private clusters" but still allow traffic to and from nodes. You may want to create a cluster with private nodes, with or without a public control plane endpoint, depending on your organization's networking and security requirements. A GKE cluster provisioned from Rancher can use isolated nodes by selecting "Private Cluster" in the Cluster Options (under "Show advanced options"). The control plane endpoint can optionally be made private by selecting "Enable Private Endpoint".

en/cluster-admin/editing-clusters/k3s-co.title: K3s Cluster Configuration Reference
en/cluster-admin/editing-clusters/k3s-co.description: This section covers the configuration options that are available in Rancher for a new or existing K3s Kubernetes cluster.

en/cluster-admin/editing-clusters/rke-co.title: RKE Cluster Configuration Reference
en/cluster-admin/editing-clusters/rke-co.description: When Rancher installs Kubernetes, it uses RKE or RKE2 as the Kubernetes distribution.

en/cluster-admin/editing-clusters/rke2-c.title: RKE2 Cluster Configuration Reference
en/cluster-admin/editing-clusters/rke2-c.description: This section covers the configuration options that are available in Rancher for a new or existing RKE2 Kubernetes cluster.

en/cluster-admin/editing-clusters/syncin.title: Syncing
en/cluster-admin/editing-clusters/syncin.description: Syncing is the feature for EKS and GKE clusters that causes Rancher to update the clusters' values so they are up to date with their corresponding cluster object in the hosted Kubernetes provider. This enables Rancher to not be the sole owner of a hosted clusterâ€™s state. Its largest limitation is that processing an update from Rancher and another source at the same time or within 5 minutes of one finishing may cause the state from one source to completely overwrite the other.

en/cluster-admin/nodes/nodes.title: Nodes and Node Pools
en/cluster-admin/nodes/nodes.description: After you launch a Kubernetes cluster in Rancher, you can manage individual nodes from the cluster's Node tab. Depending on the option used to provision the cluster, there are different node options available.

en/cluster-admin/pod-security-policies/p.title: Assigning Pod Security Policies
en/cluster-admin/pod-security-policies/p.description: Pod Security Policies are objects that control security-sensitive aspects of pod specification (like root privileges).

en/cluster-admin/projects-and-namespaces.title: Projects and Kubernetes Namespaces with Rancher
en/cluster-admin/projects-and-namespaces.description: Rancher Projects ease the administrative burden of your cluster and support multi-tenancy. Learn to create projects and divide projects into Kubernetes namespaces

en/cluster-admin/restoring-etcd/restorin.title: Restoring a Cluster from Backup
en/cluster-admin/restoring-etcd/restorin.description: etcd backup and recovery for Rancher launched Kubernetes clusters can be easily performed. Snapshots of the etcd database are taken and saved either locally onto the etcd nodes or to a S3 compatible target. The advantages of configuring S3 is that if all etcd nodes are lost, your snapshot is saved remotely and can be used to restore the cluster.

en/cluster-admin/tools/tools.title: Tools for Logging, Monitoring, and Visibility

en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-storage/exa.description: Rancher supports persistent storage with a variety of volume plugins. However, before you use any of these plugins to bind persistent storage to your workloads, you have to configure the storage itself, whether its a cloud-based solution from a service-provider or an on-prem solution that you manage yourself.

en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-storage/exa.title: NFS Storage
en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-storage/exa.description: Before you can use the NFS storage volume plug-in with Rancher deployments, you need to provision an NFS server.

en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-storage/exa.description: To provide stateful workloads with vSphere storage, we recommend creating a vSphereVolume StorageClass. This practice dynamically provisions vSphere storage when workloads request volumes through a PersistentVolumeClaim.

en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-storage/how.description: A persistent volume (PV) is a piece of storage in the Kubernetes cluster, while a persistent volume claim (PVC) is a request for storage.

en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-storage/isc.title: iSCSI Volumes
en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-storage/isc.description: In Rancher Launched Kubernetes clusters that store data on iSCSI volumes, you may experience an issue where kubelets fail to automatically connect with iSCSI volumes. This failure is likely due to an incompatibility issue involving the iSCSI initiator tool. You can resolve this issue by installing the iSCSI initiator tool on each of your cluster nodes.

en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-storage/pro.title: Dynamically Provisioning New Storage in Rancher

en/cluster-provisioning/hosted-kubernete.title: Creating an Aliyun ACK Cluster
en/cluster-provisioning/hosted-kubernete.description: You can use Rancher to create a cluster hosted in Alibaba Cloud Kubernetes (ACK). Rancher has already implemented and packaged the cluster driver for ACK, but by default, this cluster driver is inactive. In order to launch ACK clusters, you will need to enable the ACK cluster driver. After enabling the cluster driver, you can start provisioning ACK clusters.

en/cluster-provisioning/hosted-kubernete.title: Creating an AKS Cluster
en/cluster-provisioning/hosted-kubernete.description: You can use Rancher to create a cluster hosted in Microsoft Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS).

en/cluster-provisioning/hosted-kubernete.title: Creating a Huawei CCE Cluster
en/cluster-provisioning/hosted-kubernete.description: You can use Rancher to create a cluster hosted in Huawei Cloud Container Engine (CCE). Rancher has already implemented and packaged the cluster driver for CCE, but by default, this cluster driver is inactive. In order to launch CCE clusters, you will need to enable the CCE cluster driver. After enabling the cluster driver, you can start provisioning CCE clusters.

en/cluster-provisioning/hosted-kubernete.title: Creating an EKS Cluster
en/cluster-provisioning/hosted-kubernete.description: Amazon EKS provides a managed control plane for your Kubernetes cluster. Amazon EKS runs the Kubernetes control plane instances across multiple Availability Zones to ensure high availability. Rancher provides an intuitive user interface for managing and deploying the Kubernetes clusters you run in Amazon EKS. With this guide, you will use Rancher to quickly and easily launch an Amazon EKS Kubernetes cluster in your AWS account. For more information on Amazon EKS, see this documentation.

en/cluster-provisioning/hosted-kubernete.title: Minimum EKS Permissions
en/cluster-provisioning/hosted-kubernete.description: Documented here is a minimum set of permissions necessary to use all functionality of the EKS driver in Rancher. Additional permissions are required for Rancher to provision the Service Role and VPC resources. Optionally these resources can be created before the cluster creation and will be selectable when defining the cluster configuration.

en/cluster-provisioning/hosted-kubernete.title: Setting up Clusters from Hosted Kubernetes Providers
en/cluster-provisioning/hosted-kubernete.description: In this scenario, Rancher does not provision Kubernetes because it is installed by providers such as Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE), Amazon Elastic Container Service for Kubernetes, or Azure Kubernetes Service.

en/cluster-provisioning/hosted-kubernete.title: Creating a Tencent TKE Cluster
en/cluster-provisioning/hosted-kubernete.description: You can use Rancher to create a cluster hosted in Tencent Kubernetes Engine (TKE). Rancher has already implemented and packaged the cluster driver for TKE, but by default, this cluster driver is inactive. In order to launch TKE clusters, you will need to enable the TKE cluster driver. After enabling the cluster driver, you can start provisioning TKE clusters.

en/cluster-provisioning/node-requirement.description: This page describes the requirements for the Rancher managed Kubernetes clusters where your apps and services will be installed. These downstream clusters should be separate from the three-node cluster running Rancher.

en/cluster-provisioning/rke-clusters/nod.description: Creating virtual machines in a repeatable and reliable fashion can often be difficult. VMware vSphere offers the ability to build one VM that can then be converted to a template. The template can then be used to create identically configured VMs. Rancher leverages this capability within node pools to create identical RKE1 and RKE2 nodes.

en/deploy-across-clusters/fleet/architec.title: Architecture
en/deploy-across-clusters/fleet/architec.description: Fleet can manage deployments from git of raw Kubernetes YAML, Helm charts, or Kustomize or any combination of the three. Regardless of the source, all resources are dynamically turned into Helm charts, and Helm is used as the engine to deploy everything in the cluster. This gives you a high degree of control, consistency, and auditability. Fleet focuses not only on the ability to scale, but to give one a high degree of control and visibility to exactly what is installed on the cluster.

en/deploy-across-clusters/fleet/fleet.title: Fleet - GitOps at Scale
en/deploy-across-clusters/fleet/fleet.description: Fleet is GitOps at scale. Fleet is designed to manage up to a million clusters. It's also lightweight enough that it works great for a single cluster too, but it really shines when you get to a large scale. By large scale we mean either a lot of clusters, a lot of deployments, or a lot of teams in a single organization.

en/deploy-across-clusters/fleet/proxy/pr.title: Using Fleet Behind a Proxy
en/deploy-across-clusters/fleet/proxy/pr.description: In this section, you'll learn how to enable Fleet in a setup that has a Rancher server with a public IP a Kubernetes cluster that has no public IP, but is configured to use a proxy.

en/deploy-across-clusters/fleet/windows/.title: Windows Support
en/deploy-across-clusters/fleet/windows/.description: Prior to Rancher v2.5.6, the agent did not have native Windows manifests on downstream clusters with Windows nodes. This would result in a failing agent pod for the cluster.

en/deploy-across-clusters/multi-cluster-.title: Multi-cluster Apps
en/deploy-across-clusters/multi-cluster-.description: As of Rancher v2.5, multi-cluster apps are deprecated. We now recommend using Fleet for deploying apps across clusters.

en/faq/dockershim/dockershim.title: Dockershim
en/faq/dockershim/dockershim.description: The Dockershim is the CRI compliant layer between the Kubelet and the Docker daemon. As part of the Kubernetes 1.20 release, the deprecation of the in-tree Dockershim was announced. Removal is currently scheduled for Kubernetes 1.24. For more information on the deprecation and its timelines, see the Kubernetes Dockershim Deprecation FAQ.

en/helm-charts/helm.title: Helm Charts in Rancher
en/helm-charts/helm.description: In this section, you'll learn how to manage Helm chart repositories and applications in Rancher. Helm chart repositories are managed using Apps & Marketplace. It uses a catalog-like system to import bundles of charts from repositories and then uses those charts to either deploy custom Helm applications or Rancher's tools such as Monitoring or Istio. Rancher tools come as pre-loaded repositories which deploy as standalone Helm charts. Any additional repositories are only added to the current cluster.

As part of the Kubernetes 1.20 release, the deprecation of the in-tree Dockershim was announced. For more information on the deprecation and its timelines, see the Kubernetes Dockershim Deprecation FAQ.

en/installation/requirements/installing-.title: Installing Docker
en/installation/requirements/installing-.description: Docker is required to be installed on nodes where the Rancher server will be installed with Helm or Docker.

en/installation/requirements/ports/ports.title: Port Requirements
en/installation/requirements/ports/ports.description: Read about port requirements needed in order for Rancher to operate properly, both for Rancher nodes and downstream Kubernetes cluster nodes

en/installation/requirements/requirement.description: Learn the node requirements for each node running Rancher server when youâ€™re configuring  Rancher to run either in a Docker or Kubernetes setup

en/installation/resources/advanced/advan.title: Advanced
en/installation/resources/advanced/advan.description: The documents in this section contain resources for less common use cases.

en/installation/resources/advanced/api-a.title: Enabling the API Audit Log to Record System Events
en/installation/resources/advanced/api-a.description: You can enable the API audit log to record the sequence of system events initiated by individual users. You can know what happened, when it happened, who initiated it, and what cluster it affected. When you enable this feature, all requests to the Rancher API and all responses from it are written to a log.

en/installation/resources/advanced/etcd/.title: Tuning etcd for Large Installations
en/installation/resources/advanced/etcd/.description: When running larger Rancher installations with 15 or more clusters it is recommended to increase the default keyspace for etcd from the default 2GB. The maximum setting is 8GB and the host should have enough RAM to keep the entire dataset in memory. When increasing this value you should also increase the size of the host. The keyspace size can also be adjusted in smaller installations if you anticipate a high rate of change of pods during the garbage collection interval.

en/installation/resources/advanced/firew.title: Opening Ports with firewalld
en/installation/resources/advanced/firew.description: We recommend disabling firewalld. For Kubernetes 1.19.x and higher, firewalld must be turned off.

en/installation/resources/advanced/singl.title: Docker Install with TLS Termination at Layer-7 NGINX Load Balancer
en/installation/resources/advanced/singl.description: For development and testing environments that have a special requirement to terminate TLS/SSL at a load balancer instead of your Rancher Server container, deploy Rancher and configure a load balancer to work with it conjunction.

en/installation/resources/bootstrap-pass.title: Bootstrap Password
en/installation/resources/bootstrap-pass.description: When Rancher starts for the first time, a password is randomly generated for the first admin user. When the admin first logs in to Rancher, the UI shows commands that can be used to retrieve the bootstrap password. The admin needs to run those commands and log in with the bootstrap password. Then Rancher gives the admin an opportunity to reset the password.

en/installation/resources/choosing-versi.title: Choosing a Rancher Version

en/installation/resources/custom-ca-root.title: About Custom CA Root Certificates
en/installation/resources/custom-ca-root.description: If you're using Rancher in an internal production environment where you aren't exposing apps publicly, use a certificate from a private certificate authority (CA).

en/installation/resources/feature-flags/.title: Continuous Delivery
en/installation/resources/feature-flags/.description: As of Rancher v2.5, Fleet comes preinstalled in Rancher, and as of Rancher v2.6, Fleet can no longer be fully disabled. However, the Fleet feature for GitOps continuous delivery may be disabled using the continuous-delivery feature flag.

en/installation/resources/feature-flags/.title: Allow Unsupported Storage Drivers
en/installation/resources/feature-flags/.description: This feature allows you to use types for storage providers and provisioners that are not enabled by default.

en/installation/resources/feature-flags/.title: Enabling Experimental Features
en/installation/resources/feature-flags/.description: Rancher includes some features that are experimental and disabled by default. You might want to enable these features, for example, if you decide that the benefits of using an unsupported storage type outweighs the risk of using an untested feature. Feature flags were introduced to allow you to try these features that are not enabled by default.

en/installation/resources/feature-flags/.description: This feature enables a UI that lets you create, read, update and delete virtual services and destination rules, which are traffic management features of Istio.

en/pipelines/config/config.description: In this section, you'll learn how to configure pipelines.

en/pipelines/example-repos/example-repos.title: Example Repositories
en/pipelines/example-repos/example-repos.description: Rancher ships with several example repositories that you can use to familiarize yourself with pipelines. We recommend configuring and testing the example repository that most resembles your environment before using pipelines with your own repositories in a production environment. Use this example repository as a sandbox for repo configuration, build demonstration, etc. Rancher includes example repositories for:

en/pipelines/example/example.title: Example YAML File
en/pipelines/example/example.description: Pipelines can be configured either through the UI or using a yaml file in the repository, i.e. .rancher-pipeline.yml or .rancher-pipeline.yaml.

en/pipelines/pipelines.title: Pipelines
en/pipelines/pipelines.description: As of Rancher v2.5, Git-based deployment pipelines are now deprecated. We recommend handling pipelines with Rancher Continuous Delivery powered by Fleet. To get to Fleet in Rancher, click â˜° > Continuous Delivery.

en/pipelines/storage/storage.title: Configuring Persistent Data for Pipeline Components
en/pipelines/storage/storage.description: The pipelines' internal Docker registry and the Minio workloads use ephemeral volumes by default. This default storage works out-of-the-box and makes testing easy, but you lose the build images and build logs if the node running the Docker Registry or Minio fails. In most cases this is fine. If you want build images and logs to survive node failures, you can configure the Docker Registry and Minio to use persistent volumes.

en/project-admin/namespaces/namespaces.title: Namespaces
en/project-admin/namespaces/namespaces.description: Within Rancher, you can further divide projects into different namespaces, which are virtual clusters within a project backed by a physical cluster. Should you require another level of organization beyond projects and the default namespace, you can use multiple namespaces to isolate applications and resources.

en/project-admin/pipelines/pipelines.title: Rancher's CI/CD Pipelines
en/project-admin/pipelines/pipelines.description: Use Rancherâ€™s CI/CD pipeline to automatically checkout code, run builds or scripts, publish Docker images, and deploy software to users

en/project-admin/pod-security-policies/p.title: Pod Security Policies
en/project-admin/pod-security-policies/p.description: These cluster options are only available for clusters in which Rancher has launched Kubernetes.

en/project-admin/project-admin.title: Project Administration
en/project-admin/project-admin.description: Projects are objects introduced in Rancher that help organize namespaces in your Kubernetes cluster. You can use projects to create multi-tenant clusters, which allows a group of users to share the same underlying resources without interacting with each other's applications.

en/project-admin/project-members/project.title: Adding Users to Projects
en/project-admin/project-members/project.description: If you want to provide a user with access and permissions to specific projects and resources within a cluster, assign the user a project membership.

en/project-admin/resource-quotas/overrid.title: Setting Container Default Resource Limits
en/project-admin/resource-quotas/overrid.description: When setting resource quotas, if you set anything related to CPU or Memory (i.e. limits or reservations) on a project / namespace, all containers will require a respective CPU or Memory field set during creation. See the Kubernetes documentation for more details on why this is required.

en/project-admin/resource-quotas/overrid.title: Overriding the Default Limit for a Namespace
en/project-admin/resource-quotas/overrid.description: Although the Namespace Default Limit propagates from the project to each namespace when created, in some cases, you may need to increase (or decrease) the quotas for a specific namespace. In this situation, you can override the default limits by editing the namespace.

en/project-admin/resource-quotas/quota-t.title: Resource Quota Type Reference
en/project-admin/resource-quotas/quota-t.description: When you create a resource quota, you are configuring the pool of resources available to the project. You can set the following resource limits for the following resource types.

en/project-admin/resource-quotas/quotas-.title: How Resource Quotas Work in Rancher Projects
en/project-admin/resource-quotas/quotas-.description: Resource quotas in Rancher include the same functionality as the native version of Kubernetes. However, in Rancher, resource quotas have been extended so that you can apply them to projects.

en/project-admin/resource-quotas/resourc.title: Project Resource Quotas
en/project-admin/resource-quotas/resourc.description: In situations where several teams share a cluster, one team may overconsume the resources available: CPU, memory, storage, services, Kubernetes objects like pods or secrets, and so on.  To prevent this overconsumption, you can apply a resource quota, which is a Rancher feature that limits the resources available to a project or namespace.

en/project-admin/tools/tools.title: Tools for Logging, Monitoring, and Visibility
en/project-admin/tools/tools.description: Rancher contains a variety of tools that aren't included in Kubernetes to assist in your DevOps operations. Rancher can integrate with external services to help your clusters run more efficiently. Tools are divided into following categories:

en/quick-start-guide/quick-start-guide.description: Note: The intent of these guides is to quickly launch a sandbox that you can use to evaluate Rancher. These guides are not intended for production environments. For comprehensive setup instructions, see Installation.

en/quick-start-guide/workload/workload.title: Deploying Workloads
en/quick-start-guide/workload/workload.description: These guides walk you through the deployment of an application, including how to expose the application for use outside of the cluster.

en/security/cve/cve.title: Security Advisories and CVEs
en/security/cve/cve.description: Rancher is committed to informing the community of security issues in our products. Rancher will publish security advisories and CVEs (Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures) for issues we have resolved. New security advisories are also published in Rancher's GitHub security page.

en/security/hardening-guides/hardening-g.description: Rancher provides specific security hardening guides for each supported Rancher's Kubernetes distributions.

en/security/hardening-guides/rke-1.6-har.title: RKE Hardening Guide with CIS v1.6 Benchmark
en/security/hardening-guides/rke-1.6-har.description: This document provides prescriptive guidance for hardening a production installation of a RKE cluster to be used with Rancher v2.6. It outlines the configurations and controls required to address Kubernetes benchmark controls from the Center for Information Security (CIS).

en/security/hardening-guides/rke2-1.6-ha.description: This document provides prescriptive guidance for hardening a production installation of a RKE2 cluster to be provisioned with Rancher v2.6.5. It outlines the configurations and controls required to address Kubernetes benchmark controls from the Center for Information Security (CIS).

en/troubleshooting/expired-webhook-certi.title: Rotation of Expired Webhook Certificates
en/troubleshooting/expired-webhook-certi.description: For Rancher versions that have rancher-webhook installed, these certificates will expire after one year. It will be necessary for you to rotate your webhook certificate when this occurs.

en/troubleshooting/imported-clusters/imp.description: The commands/steps listed on this page can be used to check clusters that you are registering or that are registered in Rancher.

en/troubleshooting/kubernetes-components.description: The nginx-proxy container is deployed on every node that does not have the controlplane role. It provides access to all the nodes with the controlplane role by dynamically generating the NGINX configuration based on available nodes with the controlplane role.

en/troubleshooting/kubernetes-components.description: This section applies to every node as it includes components that run on nodes with any role.

en/troubleshooting/kubernetes-resources/.description: The commands/steps listed on this page can be used to check the most important Kubernetes resources and apply to Rancher Launched Kubernetes clusters.

en/user-settings/cloud-credentials/cloud.title: Managing Cloud Credentials
en/user-settings/cloud-credentials/cloud.description: When you create a cluster hosted by an infrastructure provider, node templates are used to provision the cluster nodes. These templates use Docker Machine configuration options to define an operating system image and settings/parameters for the node.

en/user-settings/node-templates/node-tem.title: Managing Node Templates
en/user-settings/node-templates/node-tem.description: When you provision a cluster hosted by an infrastructure provider, node templates are used to provision the cluster nodes. These templates use Docker Machine configuration options to define an operating system image and settings/parameters for the node. You can create node templates in two contexts:

en/user-settings/preferences/preferences.title: User Preferences
en/user-settings/preferences/preferences.description: Each user can choose preferences to personalize their Rancher experience. To change preference settings, open the User Settings menu and then select Preferences.

en/user-settings/user-settings.title: User Settings
en/user-settings/user-settings.description: Within Rancher, each user has a number of settings associated with their login: personal preferences, API keys, etc. You can configure these settings by choosing from the User Settings menu. You can open this menu by clicking your avatar, located within the main menu.
